history.title: The Beginning
history.desc: Visual representations of information have been used for thousands of years. Humans have always felt the urge to record their thoughts and present these to others – in both analog and digital formats.

history.title: The Father
history.desc: The term “mind map” appeared in the 1970s, when it was coined on the BBC by Tony Buzan, the “father of mind mapping.” Originally, Buzan had developed mind maps to memorize information at university.

history.title: The Method
history.desc: Buzan studied great thinkers and combined their approaches with his own research in psychology, creative thinking and memorization. His summary, “The Mind Map Book,” appeared in 1995.

history.title: Branching Out
history.desc: The modern definition of mind mapping encompasses spider maps and bubble maps as well. These are variations on the Buzan method, but maintain the radiant structure and hierarchy of mind maps.

history.title: Going Online
history.desc: In 2007, the first web-based mind map tool was released: MindMeister. With billions of ideas generated by over 37 million users worldwide, the tool has revolutionized ideation for business and education.

history.title: Enter the Panda
history.desc: MindMeister underwent an extensive update in 2021 to adapt the tool to the evolving user needs. Feedback from thousands of mind mappers helped create an all-new MindMeister – Project Panda.
